title: Cox's Bazar
description: Cox's Bazar is home to the world's longest natural sea beach, stretching over 120 kilometers along the southeastern coast of Bangladesh. Known for its golden sands, vibrant beach life, and the scenic views of the Bay of Bengal, it attracts millions of local and international tourists each year. Popular attractions include Inani Beach, Himchari Waterfall, and the marine drive.

title: Sajek
description: Sajek Valley, nestled in the hills of the Rangamati district in the Chittagong Hill Tracts, is known for its spectacular natural beauty and cloud-kissed landscapes. Situated about 1,800 feet above sea level, it offers breathtaking views of rolling hills, sunrise and sunset points, and indigenous culture. The valley is especially famous for its tranquil environment and is often referred to as the 'Queen of Hills' in Bangladesh.

title: Sreemangal
description: Sreemangal, located in the Moulvibazar district of Sylhet, is widely known as the tea capital of Bangladesh. The area is famous for its lush green tea gardens, rolling hills, and diverse wildlife. Tourists often visit to explore the Lawachara National Park, trek through rainforests, and taste the unique seven-layer tea. Sreemangal offers a peaceful retreat for nature lovers and adventure seekers alike.

title: Sundarbans
description: The Sundarbans is the largest mangrove forest in the world and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, located in the southwestern part of Bangladesh. It is famous for being the habitat of the elusive Royal Bengal Tiger, along with crocodiles, spotted deer, and numerous bird species. Crisscrossed by a complex network of tidal waterways, mudflats, and small islands, the Sundarbans offers unique experiences in wildlife tourism and eco-travel.
